alt_statements.statement: I think police should treat everyone fairly and with respect, no matter what they look like or where they come from, because God teaches us that everyone is equal and deserves kindness. They should get better training to calm situations down instead of going straight to force, and use cameras and clear rules so people can trust that they’re doing the right thing. At the same time, we still need police to keep our neighborhoods safe, so working together with the community and listening to kids and families can help everyone feel safer and more understood.

As someone who cares about both community safety and fairness, I think police departments need stronger de-escalation training, clear limits on use of force, and real accountability when officers cross the line—including independent investigations. Bias training alone isn’t enough; we need better screening and ongoing evaluations to keep people with aggressive or prejudiced tendencies off the force in the first place. At the same time, I want officers supported with good pay, mental health resources, and staffing levels so they’re not constantly operating on adrenaline and burnout. Public safety and civil rights aren’t competing goals—if people don’t trust the police, they’re less likely to cooperate, and that makes everyone less safe.

I think police officers should be super careful and kind, like real-life superheroes who protect people but don’t hurt them unless they really have to. They should treat everyone fairly no matter what they look like, and maybe learn more about the people in their neighborhoods so they don’t get scared or angry too fast. My parents say good rules and training can help stop bad things from happening, and I believe God wants us to keep people safe without being cruel.

As a mom and a library worker who serves all kinds of people every day, I want policing that is both fair and effective—officers should be trained thoroughly in de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health crisis response, and held accountable when they abuse their authority. At the same time, I recognize that we rely on the police to keep our communities and our kids safe, so reforms should focus on better training, clearer standards for use of force, and stronger community oversight rather than weakening public safety.

As someone who believes in both accountability and public safety, I think policing needs clear, enforceable standards on use of force, strong independent oversight, and mandatory body cameras to reduce bias and rebuild trust. We should invest heavily in de-escalation training, anti-bias education, mental health crisis teams, and community-based violence prevention so officers aren’t responding to every social problem with force. At the same time, departments must collect and publicly report detailed data on stops, searches, and force by race and geography so we can actually measure progress and hold leadership responsible for systemic change.

As someone who works in national security and believes in law and order, I think we absolutely need to address bias and excessive force in policing, but we have to do it in a way that doesn’t undermine officers who put their lives on the line every day. The focus should be on better training in de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, along with clear, consistently enforced standards and body camera use—backed by leadership that supports good cops and removes bad ones quickly. We should use data to identify problem patterns and departments, but any reforms have to be grounded in facts, not politics, and must keep public safety and officer safety at the center.

As someone who cares deeply about law and order but also about basic fairness, I believe we need policing that is both firm and accountable. Officers should have strong training in de-escalation and clear, consistently enforced standards on use of force, with body cameras and transparent review processes when things go wrong. At the same time, we must support good officers, give them the resources they need, and avoid blanket condemnations that make their jobs harder and our communities less safe.

As a Nicaraguan Muslim who believes in social justice, I think policing needs to be rooted in accountability, transparency, and genuine community partnership, especially in immigrant and minority neighborhoods. Departments should adopt strict use-of-force standards, require body cameras and independent review of misconduct, and invest heavily in de-escalation and anti-bias training, while redirecting some responsibilities—like mental health crises—to specialized responders. This kind of approach doesn’t weaken public safety; it strengthens trust, so officers can do their jobs more effectively and communities feel protected rather than targeted.

I think police officers should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and kindly, no matter what they look like, because everyone’s life is important. They should get special training to calm people down without hurting them, and only use force when there’s truly no other choice to keep people safe. I feel safer when I imagine officers who are like good heroes, protecting people and listening to the community, instead of scaring them.

As a high school teacher and lifelong Wisconsinite, I see every day how trust in institutions—or the lack of it—shapes young people’s outlook on their own future and their community. We need policing strategies grounded in rigorous de-escalation training, transparent accountability (including independent review of use-of-force incidents), and strong community partnerships that reflect our racial and cultural diversity. When officers know the neighborhoods they serve, and residents feel heard and respected rather than targeted, we’re better able to prevent crime instead of just reacting to it. That kind of approach not only reduces bias and unnecessary force, it also makes our communities safer and more cohesive in the long run.

As a 17-year-old who cares a lot about fairness and community, I think policing needs stronger de-escalation training, clear accountability for officers who abuse their power, and better bias training to address racism and discrimination. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, youth programs, and community resources so police don’t have to be the answer to every problem, which would improve public safety in a more humane and sustainable way.

As a cop and a conservative, I believe we can address bias and use-of-force concerns without tying officers’ hands or compromising public safety. We need solid training based on real-world scenarios, clear use-of-force policies that are actually enforced, and body cameras that protect both the public and the officers. I support transparency and holding bad actors accountable, but I also expect the public and elected officials to respect the dangers of this job and not rush to judgment before the facts are in. The goal should be fair, consistent policing that treats everyone with dignity while still allowing us to do what’s necessary to protect our communities and get home safe to our families.

As a Catholic and a Democrat who cares deeply about both justice and community safety, I believe policing needs strong, transparent accountability measures, including independent review of use-of-force incidents and robust data collection on stops and arrests to root out bias. At the same time, we should invest heavily in de-escalation training, mental health crisis teams, and community-based prevention so officers aren’t asked to solve every social problem with force. I want my tax dollars supporting a system where everyone—especially people of color—can trust that the law is enforced fairly, and where officers are well-trained professionals who are held to high standards and given the right tools to do their jobs safely.

Como mujer mayor que ha trabajado duro toda su vida y valora el orden y la seguridad, creo que la policía es necesaria para proteger a las familias y a los barrios, pero debe hacerlo con respeto y justicia para todos, sin importar raza, idioma o estatus migratorio. Se necesita mejor entrenamiento en control de emociones, en cómo tratar a las personas con dignidad, y en reducir el uso de la fuerza solo a lo estrictamente necesario, junto con más oficiales que conozcan la comunidad, hablen nuestro idioma y trabajen con las iglesias y organizaciones locales. De esta manera se puede mantener la seguridad pública, pero también la confianza y el respeto entre la comunidad y la policía.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a hard job, and we still need strong law enforcement to keep communities safe. At the same time, departments should be held to high standards: better training on de-escalation, body cameras, and clear consequences when officers abuse their authority. We can support the police and still expect them to treat everyone fairly, without bias. Cutting their funding isn’t the answer; improving hiring, training, and accountability is.

As someone who works long hours in a high-pressure kitchen, I understand how stressful jobs can be, but that can’t be an excuse for unfair treatment or excessive force from police. We need strong, consistent training that focuses on de-escalation, clear rules about when force is justified, and real accountability when officers cross the line, while still giving good officers the support and respect they deserve. I want police who know the neighborhoods they serve, including immigrant communities like mine, and who treat everyone the same regardless of race or accent. That balance—firm law enforcement with strict standards and respect—is what keeps both the public and officers safe.

As someone who spent a career making high-stakes decisions in banking, I believe policing needs clear standards, strong training, and real accountability to handle bias and use-of-force concerns without undermining officers who do their jobs honorably. We should invest in better de-escalation and community-based policing, insist on body cameras and transparent review processes, and use data to spot patterns of discrimination. At the same time, we must support law enforcement with the resources and public backing they need to keep neighborhoods safe, because without order and security, none of our communities can truly thrive.

As a Christian and someone who works every day with people in need, I believe policing must be rooted in both fairness and accountability, without weakening the protection our communities rely on. Departments should invest in strong training on de-escalation and bias, enforce clear consequences for misconduct, and build real relationships with neighborhoods so officers see people as neighbors, not threats. At the same time, we must support good officers with the resources and respect they need to confront crime, because families—especially our children—deserve to feel safe in their homes and on their streets. Through prayer, personal responsibility, and honest dialogue between law enforcement and the community, I believe we can reduce unnecessary use of force while maintaining order and justice.

As someone who’s seen a lot in my 92 years, I believe we need law and order, but we also need cops who treat everyone fairly and answer for their mistakes. Training should focus on de-escalation, knowing the community, and recognizing bias, but we shouldn’t handcuff good officers from doing their jobs and keeping folks safe. Strong oversight that’s local and transparent can help rebuild trust without tearing down the whole system.

I think cops should get way more training on how to calm situations down without jumping straight to force, and they should have body cameras on all the time so there’s proof of what really happened. There also needs to be real consequences when an officer clearly acts with bias or goes too far, instead of it just getting covered up. At the same time, we still need police to respond fast when there’s actual danger, so better training and accountability should help them protect people while treating everyone fairly.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in basic fairness, I think policing needs stricter standards, better training in de-escalation, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We should support good cops with the tools and staffing they need to keep communities safe, while using body cameras, transparent investigations, and bias training to make sure everyone—no matter their background—is treated with respect.

I back the police because I know they’ve got a tough, dangerous job, but I also think nobody should be above the law, including officers. We need more body cams, better training on de-escalation and bias, and real accountability when someone crosses the line. That way, good cops are protected, bad ones are weeded out, and folks like me can feel safer on the road and in our communities without feeling like our rights are getting trampled.

As a Mexican immigrant, a mother, and a preschool teacher, I want my children and the kids I teach to feel safe around police, not afraid of them. We need strong bias training, clear consequences for excessive force, and body cameras, but also better community policing where officers get to know families and earn our trust. Public safety matters, but it can’t come at the cost of treating some communities—especially Latino and Black neighborhoods—as suspects first and people second. Real accountability and transparency will make everyone safer, including good officers who do their jobs with integrity.

As a Black man who works campus security, I see firsthand how trust between officers and the community can make or break public safety. Policing needs stronger accountability, de-escalation training, and real consequences for excessive force, along with recruiting officers who reflect the communities they serve. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, education, and social support so police aren’t the only response to every problem. When people feel respected and heard, it’s easier to keep everyone safe without resorting to force.

I respect the police and believe most of them are trying to do a hard job the best they can, but I also think they should be held accountable when they use force improperly or treat people unfairly. To me, the answer is better training in de-escalation, body cameras that are always on, and firm consequences for misconduct, while still giving officers the tools and support they need to deal with real crime.

I believe most police officers are trying to do a hard job and keep our communities safe, but we can’t ignore that bias and excessive force do happen and need to be dealt with honestly. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and mental health, require body cameras and real accountability for abuses, and still make sure police have the tools and support they need to respond quickly to crime. That balance—respecting citizens’ rights while backing good officers—is what will build trust and keep our neighborhoods safer.

As someone who works in information security, I believe policing should be guided by data-driven accountability: body cameras, transparent reporting, and independent review of use-of-force incidents so we can clearly see and fix patterns of bias. We ought to invest heavily in de-escalation training, mental health crisis response, and community-based partnerships, because real public safety comes from trust and prevention, not just force. As a liberal Democrat and a Catholic, I see reducing excessive force and racial bias as both a moral obligation and a practical necessity for a just society.

As someone who has spent a career in civil service and values law and order, I believe most police officers are trying to do a difficult job the right way, and they deserve our respect and support. At the same time, clear standards, strong training in de-escalation, and consistent, fair accountability are necessary to address bias and excessive use of force. We should use better technology, body cameras, and data to spot patterns of misconduct early, while making sure officers have the resources and backing they need to keep the public safe.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a hard job, and we need to support them with better training in de-escalation and communication so they can handle tense situations without resorting to force whenever possible. At the same time, there should be clear, consistent standards and accountability for misconduct so that communities, especially minority communities, can trust that officers are held to the law just like everyone else. We don’t need to “defund” the police; we need to equip them, morally and practically, to serve and protect fairly while keeping our neighborhoods safe.

My mom says police should treat everyone fair and not be mean just because of how they look or where they’re from. I think they should have special rules and training to help them stay calm and not hurt people unless they really have to. It’s important they keep us safe, but also listen to our community and say sorry and fix things when they do something wrong.

As someone who cares deeply about my community and the safety of every neighbor, I believe policing must be rooted in accountability, bias training, and de-escalation, with clear consequences when officers misuse force. We can maintain public safety by investing in community-based programs, mental health responders, and strong partnerships between police and residents, so officers are not the only answer to every crisis.

As a 78-year-old Black man who’s seen both the best and worst of law enforcement, I believe we need honest reforms that address bias and excessive force without tearing down the good officers who keep our communities safe. Police should receive better training in de-escalation and dealing with mental health and disabilities, and bad actors should be held accountable, but we also need to support officers with proper resources and staffing so they can do their jobs well. I think building trust through community policing, body cameras, and consistent standards of conduct can improve safety for everyone. And as a Catholic and a conservative, I believe in law and order, but it must always be carried out with respect for the dignity and rights of every person.

As someone who values personal responsibility and individual rights, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures and better training in de-escalation and bias awareness, so everyone is treated fairly regardless of who they are. At the same time, I want officers to feel supported in doing a tough job, with clear rules and body cameras to protect both the public and the police. We don’t have to choose between safety and justice—we need policies and leadership that insist on both.

As someone who believes in evidence-based approaches and works in a data-driven scientific field, I think policing strategies must be grounded in rigorous research on bias, de-escalation, and community outcomes, not just tradition or intuition. We should prioritize mandatory body cameras, transparent data collection on stops and use-of-force, and strong, independent oversight to identify and correct patterns of bias. At the same time, well-trained officers using non-lethal tools, mental health co-responders, and community-based violence interruption can maintain public safety more effectively than a purely punitive model. From a progressive and faith-informed perspective, the goal should be to protect human dignity and equal treatment under the law while keeping communities genuinely safe, not just heavily policed.

As a young mom and a woman of color, I want my family and community to feel both protected and respected, so I believe policing has to center on de-escalation, bias training, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We need more community-based approaches—like mental health responders, youth programs, and officers who actually know and serve the neighborhoods they patrol—so that calling the police doesn’t feel like a risk, especially for people of color.

I think police should be nice and fair to everybody and not hurt people unless they really have to, because everyone deserves to feel safe, like my family and me. They should learn how to listen and talk calmly first, and not be mean just because someone looks different. If police treated people more kindly and shared help instead of always using force, then kids like me wouldn’t be so scared when we see them.

I think police should have to follow stricter rules and real consequences around use of force and racial profiling, because everyone deserves to feel safe and treated fairly, no matter what they look like or where they’re from. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be protected, so I’d rather see officers trained better in things like de-escalation and mental health, and have them get to know our communities instead of just showing up when something goes wrong.

As a retired teacher and a lifelong Democrat, I believe policing should prioritize de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, and strong accountability measures so that no one is treated differently because of their race, income, or neighborhood. We can maintain public safety by investing in mental health services, community programs, and non-police responses for crises, while ensuring that officers who misuse force are held transparently and consistently accountable.

As someone who spent a career in a safety-focused, rules-driven environment, I believe policing should be guided by clear, consistently enforced standards that hold officers accountable without undermining their ability to do a tough job. We should invest in rigorous training on de-escalation, mental health, and constitutional rights, backed up by body cameras and transparent review processes so that bias and excessive force are identified and corrected. At the same time, we must support officers with proper staffing, equipment, and leadership so they can enforce the law firmly and fairly, especially in high-risk situations. Public safety depends on both the community’s trust in the police and the police having the confidence that, if they follow the rules, their communities and leaders will stand behind them.

As someone who spent many years teaching children right from wrong, I believe policing should be rooted in fairness, restraint, and accountability, with strong training to recognize and reduce bias. Officers need clear, consistently enforced standards on use of force, along with body cameras and transparent review processes, so the public can trust that mistakes are addressed. At the same time, we must ensure they have the support, resources, and community relationships needed to keep neighborhoods safe, especially through de-escalation and problem-solving approaches rather than force as a first resort.

I think police should be really careful and kind to people, and not hurt anyone unless they really have to, like if someone is in danger. My parents say everyone should be treated fairly no matter what they look like, and I believe that too, because that’s what we learn at church about loving others. I want police officers to help keep us safe, especially kids, but also to listen more and try to calm things down before using force.

As a Filipino American and a naturalized citizen who believes in both public safety and social justice, I think policing must be guided by strong accountability measures, mandatory de-escalation and bias training, and complete transparency in use-of-force incidents. We can keep communities safe while reducing harm by investing in mental health responders, community-based programs, and clearer standards for when force is appropriate—backed by independent oversight and real consequences when those standards are violated.

I’m only 10, but from what I see on the news and hear adults talk about, I think police should be trained more to control their reactions and treat everyone the same, no matter their race or where they’re from. I want the police to protect families like mine and keep neighborhoods safe, but they should use force only when they absolutely have to and always be held accountable if they hurt someone unfairly. More conversations between police and communities in schools, churches, and parks could help people trust each other and prevent problems before they start.

As someone who backs law enforcement and believes in personal responsibility, I think we need strong, well-trained police who can do their jobs without being handcuffed by politics, but also held to clear, fair standards on use of force. Bias and abuse should be dealt with firmly through better training, body cameras, and real accountability, not blanket hatred of cops. At the same time, communities—especially Black communities like the one I’m from—have to work with officers, not against them, so we can keep our neighborhoods safe and build mutual respect.

As a physician and a Catholic, I believe policing must be grounded in the same principles we strive for in medicine: respect for human dignity, evidence-based practice, and accountability. We should invest in rigorous bias training, transparent data collection on stops and use of force, stronger community oversight, and non-police responses for mental health and low-level issues, while ensuring officers are well-supported and trained to de-escalate. Done properly, these reforms do not weaken public safety; they strengthen it by building trust, reducing unnecessary harm, and allowing police to focus on the most serious threats to the community.

As a mom raising kids in a busy community and someone who believes deeply in fairness, I think our policing strategies need to center on de-escalation, bias training, and real accountability so everyone is treated with dignity, no matter their background. We can support officers in doing a tough job by giving them better training, mental health resources, and clear rules on use of force, while also investing in community programs, school support, and social services that prevent crime in the first place.

I think police should have strict rules and constant training so they don’t judge people by race or how they look, because that just makes communities scared instead of safe. There should be body cameras, clear consequences when officers use force unfairly, and more officers who actually know and talk to the people in our neighborhoods. If police worked with local churches, schools, and youth groups, they could prevent problems before they turn violent. Protecting people’s rights and treating everyone with respect is part of real public safety, not something separate from it.

As someone who spends all day driving around this city and talking with people from every walk of life, I see how much damage is done when communities don’t trust the police—especially when bias and excessive force go unaddressed. We need strict accountability measures, body cameras, de-escalation and anti-bias training, and independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, alongside diverting many mental health and low-level issues to specialized responders instead of armed officers. At the same time, I want well-trained officers who are part of the community, not an occupying force—people who know the neighborhoods, walk the streets, and build relationships so that safety comes from cooperation, not fear.

As someone who works long hours, raises kids, and just wants them to get home safe, I think policing has to be both fair and effective. We need strong accountability and de-escalation training to reduce bias and unnecessary force, but we also need well-supported officers who know our communities and can respond quickly when things go wrong. I’d like to see more investment in community-based programs and mental health responders so police aren’t the only answer to every problem, while still making sure violent crime is taken seriously. In the end, safety and respect should go hand in hand—no one should have to choose between being protected and being treated fairly.

As a mom and someone who cares deeply about safety in my community, I believe we need strong, well-supported police who are held to high standards and trained thoroughly in de-escalation, cultural awareness, and recognizing their own biases. We should use body cameras, clear use-of-force policies, and real accountability when officers cross the line, but we also need to publicly back the many good officers who put their lives on the line every day. Departments should prioritize hiring officers who are rooted in the communities they serve and reward those who build trust through respectful, consistent engagement. That balance—firm support for law enforcement alongside firm expectations for fairness—is what will keep both our families and our freedoms safe.

I think police should have to go through really strong training on bias, de-escalation, and mental health so they’re less likely to use force unless it’s absolutely necessary. There should be body cameras that are actually checked, and real consequences when officers abuse their power, because people need to trust them. At the same time, communities should get more support like youth programs, mental health services, and safe spaces so cops aren’t the only answer to every problem. That way, public safety is about preventing harm in the first place, not just reacting to it.

As someone who cares deeply about both law and order and the well-being of my community, I believe policing strategies must focus on rigorous training, clear standards, and accountability to reduce bias and excessive force while still empowering officers to do their jobs effectively. We should invest in better de-escalation training, body cameras, and data transparency on stops and use-of-force, while also making sure officers have the resources and backup they need in dangerous situations. I support reforms that improve professionalism and trust, but I oppose broad measures that demonize police or make them hesitant to act when public safety is at risk.

As a Black man raising kids in this country, I want policing that keeps my family safe without treating us like suspects first. We need strict accountability for excessive force, better training around de-escalation and bias, and more officers who know and reflect the communities they serve. At the same time, I don’t want chaos—I want well-resourced alternatives like mental health responders and youth programs working alongside police, so safety isn’t only about a badge and a gun. Like music, real public safety should be collaborative, respectful, and built on trust, not fear.

As a Vietnamese American woman who values personal growth and social equality, I believe policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, cultural competency, and strong community relationships to reduce bias and unnecessary use of force. Officers should receive continuous training on implicit bias and mental health crises, and there must be real accountability and transparency when force is used, so communities—especially immigrants and people of color—can feel safe calling for help. At the same time, investing in social services, like mental health care and youth programs, will support public safety more effectively than relying on aggressive policing alone.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a tough job, and we need to support them with better training on de-escalation and bias so they can make good decisions under pressure. We should hold officers accountable when they clearly cross the line, but not undermine their ability to enforce the law and keep our communities safe. Body cameras, clear use-of-force policies, and strong community relationships can help rebuild trust without tying the hands of the police.

As a retired teacher and lifelong Democrat, I believe good policing is possible only when officers are held to high standards of accountability, transparency, and respect for every person they serve. We need stronger de-escalation training, independent investigations of use-of-force, and real consequences for misconduct, especially in cases that involve racial bias. At the same time, communities will be safer if we invest more in mental health care, education, and neighborhood programs so that police aren’t asked to solve every social problem with a gun and a badge.

As a Black Jamaican American woman, a nurse, and a Catholic, I believe policing must be grounded in the same principles that guide good healthcare: respect, empathy, accountability, and evidence-based practice. We need stronger bias training, transparent consequences for misuse of force, and deeper community engagement so officers know and are known by the people they serve, especially in communities of color. At the same time, officers should be well-supported, well-trained in de-escalation, and held to consistent professional standards so they can protect public safety without resorting to unnecessary violence. Compassion and innovation are not soft ideals—they are practical tools for building trust and saving lives on our streets just as they are in our hospitals.

As someone who works in public safety IT and cares deeply about my community, I believe we need policing strategies that both protect officers and the public while holding everyone to high standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, consistent use-of-force policies, and body cameras to increase transparency, but also make sure officers have the resources and support they need to do a dangerous job. I support fair accountability for misconduct, but I don’t believe in weakening law enforcement to the point where families like mine feel less safe in their own neighborhoods.

I think police should be trained to treat everyone fairly and not judge people because of their race or where they’re from, because that’s what Jesus teaches about loving your neighbor. They should learn more ways to calm people down without using force unless it’s really, truly necessary to keep someone safe. I also think officers should have to wear body cameras and explain what happened when they hurt someone so people can trust them more.

I think police should try really hard to be fair to everyone and listen to people, especially in neighborhoods like mine where families and kids just want to feel safe. They should learn not to treat people differently because of how they look or where their family is from, and only use force if they really, really have to. I like when police talk to kids at school or in parks and explain what they do, because then we can trust them more and not be as scared.

As a liberal-leaning, data-driven person who believes in both fairness and safety, I think policing needs clear, enforceable standards that minimize bias and excessive force while still giving officers the tools they need to protect communities. That means national use-of-force guidelines, mandatory body cameras, robust de-escalation and implicit-bias training, and independent civilian oversight with real teeth. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, community programs, and non-police crisis responders so officers aren’t asked to be social workers, therapists, and law enforcement all at once. Done right, these reforms can build trust, reduce tragic encounters, and actually make neighborhoods safer for everyone—including the police.

As someone who’s grown up in a liberal, multicultural environment and cares a lot about community life, I think policing needs to prioritize de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and transparent data on stops and use of force to confront racial bias head-on. At the same time, real public safety comes from investing in mental health services, education, and community programs—especially for young people—so police aren’t the default response to every social problem.

As someone who cares deeply about both fairness and safety in my community, I believe policing needs stronger accountability, better de‑escalation and bias training, and clear limits on use of force so everyone is treated with dignity. At the same time, officers should be supported with good training, mental health resources, and community partnerships—like working with local centers and schools—so they can prevent crime without resorting to violence.

I think police should treat everybody fair, like how my teachers say to treat kids at school, and not be rough with people just because of how they look or where they’re from. They should have really good training to calm people down and only use force when they absolutely have to, kind of like how grown-ups should use words before yelling. At the same time, we still need police to keep our neighborhoods safe so kids can play outside and go to church and school without being scared.

As someone who works with young children every day, I believe policing strategies should center on de-escalation, implicit bias training, and strong accountability so that kids grow up seeing law enforcement as protectors, not threats. We need community-based policing that truly partners with families and neighborhoods, transparent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and clear consequences when officers abuse their power. At the same time, adequately resourcing departments for training and mental health support can help officers make better decisions in high-stress situations, which ultimately keeps everyone safer.

My mom says police should be fair to everyone and not hurt people unless they really, really have to, and I think that’s important because everyone should feel safe, even when they look or act different. I think police should learn how to calm people down with words first and be kind, like the helpers at my church, so kids like me aren’t scared of them.

As someone who values both fairness and safety, I believe policing needs strong, enforced standards that minimize bias and unnecessary use of force—things like better training in de-escalation, more diverse hiring, and independent oversight. We should invest more in mental health services and community-based programs so police aren’t the default response to every problem, but I still want them well-trained and well-supported to handle real threats. Body cameras, transparent reporting, and real accountability when officers misuse force are essential for rebuilding trust between police and the communities they serve.

As someone who’s seen a lot of changes over 75 years, I believe we can have both safe communities and fair, accountable policing if we’re willing to be honest about bias and hold officers to high standards. Police should get strong de-escalation and bias training, wear body cameras, and face real consequences when they abuse their power, while also working closely with neighborhoods so people feel protected, not targeted. I’d like to see more funding for mental health and social services so officers aren’t the only ones responding to every crisis, and so force truly becomes a last resort.

As a progressive Christian, a dad of young kids, and someone who works with data and systems every day, I think we need policing that is both accountable and truly community-centered. That means strong, transparent use-of-force standards, independent oversight, body cams, and real consequences for misconduct, alongside investments in mental health responders, social services, and youth programs so police aren’t the default for every crisis. Bias training alone isn’t enough—we need policies and incentives that measurably reduce racial disparities in stops, arrests, and force. Done right, these reforms don’t weaken public safety; they make everyone, especially communities of color, genuinely safer and more trusting of the system.

I respect the tough job police have, and I want them to go home safe at the end of their shifts, but I also know that as a Black man, bias and excessive force are real concerns in our communities. We should focus on better training in de-escalation and bias awareness, clear and consistent accountability when officers cross the line, and more use of body cameras so everyone knows the facts. At the same time, we can’t handcuff good officers from doing their jobs—strong, fair law enforcement is essential to keeping our neighborhoods safe and stable.

As someone who works directly with vulnerable individuals and families, I’ve seen how mistrust of police can deepen trauma and make communities less safe, not more. Policing needs stronger bias training, transparent accountability for excessive force, and real community oversight, but it also needs to invest in alternatives like mental health responders and social services so officers aren’t the default answer to every crisis. I believe public safety is best protected when police see themselves as partners with the community—especially communities of color—rather than enforcers standing above it.

As a mom, a teacher, and a progressive Democrat, I want my kids to grow up in a community where they can trust the police and where no one is treated differently because of their race or background. We need stronger de-escalation and bias training, independent investigations when force is used, and clear accountability when officers violate standards—because rules without consequences change nothing. At the same time, investing in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based supports will prevent many situations from escalating to police involvement in the first place, which ultimately keeps both residents and officers safer.

As a conservative, family-oriented high school teacher, I believe we need policing strategies that both hold officers accountable and allow them to do their jobs effectively. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and bias, ensure body cameras are consistently used and footage reviewed, and enforce clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, we must support law enforcement with the resources, staffing, and public backing they need to keep communities—especially our kids—safe. Balancing firm accountability with strong support for good officers is the best way to reduce use-of-force incidents without sacrificing public safety.

As a public school teacher, I see every day how trust and fairness are essential for any authority figure to be effective, and I think the same must apply to policing. We need stronger bias training grounded in real community engagement, clearer and stricter use-of-force standards with real accountability, and investments in mental health and social services so officers aren’t the only response to every crisis. At the same time, I believe thoughtful reforms should support good officers and give them the tools and staffing they need to keep communities safe. In the long run, public safety depends as much on equity and opportunity as it does on enforcement, and our policing strategies should reflect that.

As both a nurse on a college campus and an active community volunteer, I believe policing must prioritize de-escalation, bias training, and mental health partnerships so force truly becomes a last resort. We can maintain public safety while insisting on transparency, data-driven accountability, and independent review of use-of-force incidents, especially in communities of color that have historically borne the brunt of over-policing. I’d like to see officers selected and promoted for empathy and communication skills, much like in healthcare, where trust and respect are essential to doing the job well.

As someone who cuts hair in my community every day and hears people’s stories, I think policing needs stronger accountability, better training on de-escalation and bias, and real transparency so people feel safe calling for help. We can keep communities safe without treating certain neighborhoods or races like they’re automatically suspicious, and that starts with officers actually knowing and respecting the people they serve.

As a mom raising young kids and someone who believes deeply in fairness and equal treatment, I think policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, transparent investigations, and independent oversight—to address bias and excessive force. We should invest more in de-escalation training, mental health crisis teams, and community-based programs so officers aren’t asked to be social workers, and so minor issues don’t escalate into violent encounters. At the same time, I want well-trained, properly resourced officers who are part of the community and focused on building trust, so that everyone—especially people of color—can feel both protected and respected.

As someone who works hard for a living and believes in law and order, I think we need strong, well-funded police who can keep our communities safe, but also clear rules and training so officers are held to a fair, consistent standard. I support body cameras, better de-escalation training, and swift discipline when an officer clearly abuses their power, but I don’t think we should demonize all cops for the actions of a few. We should focus on practical reforms—like improved hiring, supervision, and mental health support for officers—so they can do their jobs professionally and without bias. That way, people can feel safe both from criminals and from the fear of being treated unfairly by the system.

My mom tells me that police should be fair to everyone and not hurt people just because of how they look, and I think that sounds right. I feel safer knowing they could help if something bad happens, but I want them to listen, be calm, and talk nicely so people aren’t scared.

I think police should try really hard to be fair and nice to everybody, no matter what they look like, and only use force when there is no other way to keep people safe. They should talk and listen more first, like my teacher does when kids argue, and learn about different kinds of people so they don’t treat anyone unfairly.

I believe most police officers are good people doing a tough job, and we need to support them while also holding them to high professional standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and recognizing bias, along with body cameras and clear, consistently enforced use-of-force policies. At the same time, we must ensure officers have the resources, staffing, and community backing they need to keep neighborhoods safe. Open communication between law enforcement and the community—through town halls, ride-alongs, and local partnerships—can build trust and reduce misunderstandings on all sides.

As someone who serves in the military, I believe in strong, disciplined law enforcement that protects the public while holding its own ranks to rigorous, transparent standards. Police should receive intensive, ongoing training in de-escalation, cultural competence, and use-of-force judgment—similar to how we’re trained to handle force responsibly in uniform—paired with body cameras, clear rules of engagement, and real accountability when those rules are broken. At the same time, we shouldn’t undermine officers who do their jobs correctly; they need resources, community support, and clear leadership so they can enforce the law fairly and firmly without hesitation.

As someone who approaches problems analytically and values both individual rights and community well‑being, I think policing strategies need to be grounded in data, transparency, and accountability. We should rigorously track and publicly report use-of-force incidents and stops by race and circumstance, invest in de‑escalation and bias training that’s actually evaluated for effectiveness, and shift appropriate responsibilities—like mental health crises—away from armed officers to specialized responders. At the same time, communities deserve to be safe, so departments need strong, evidence-based policies that target serious crime while building trust through community engagement and independent oversight.

As someone who’s liberal and active in my community, I think policing needs more transparency and accountability, like body cameras, independent investigations, and real consequences when officers misuse force or show bias. At the same time, I don’t want neighborhoods to feel unsafe, so I support better training in de-escalation, bias awareness, and mental health response, plus shifting some responsibilities to social workers and community programs. That way, cops can focus on serious crime while trust grows between officers and the people they’re supposed to protect.

As someone who grew up Black in Mississippi and spent my life teaching teenagers, I believe we need both firm law enforcement and fair law enforcement. Police should get strong training on de-escalation, bias, and dealing with folks in crisis, and departments should be transparent and held accountable when force is used. At the same time, officers need clear backing to confront real violent crime, because without basic safety, none of our other rights or freedoms mean much. We don’t need to “defund” the police—we need to reform, support, and closely supervise them so they serve every neighborhood with respect.

As a retired woman who’s seen a lot of news and heartbreak over the years, I believe police need much stronger accountability, de-escalation training, and clear standards to prevent bias and excessive force, especially against communities of color. At the same time, I know communities still need to feel safe, so we should invest in mental health services, social workers, and community-based programs that can handle many situations without armed officers being the first resort.

As someone who spent her career working to protect both the environment and public health, I believe policing should be guided by evidence-based practices that reduce harm and build trust, especially in communities that have historically borne the brunt of bias and excessive force. We need strong accountability measures, rigorous de-escalation and anti-bias training, transparent data on stops and use of force, and a greater investment in social services and community-based programs so that police are not the default response to every problem. At the same time, I support well-trained officers who see themselves as partners with the community, not occupiers, and who are given the tools and oversight necessary to keep everyone safe—civilians and officers alike.

As a liberal, tech-focused professional and a dad, I want policing strategies that are both data-driven and deeply humane. We should be using technology—like body cameras, transparent data dashboards, and rigorous analytics—to identify and reduce bias and excessive force, paired with strong accountability measures and independent oversight. At the same time, we need to invest in better training around de-escalation and mental health, and shift some responsibilities to social services so officers aren’t the default for every crisis. That’s how we maintain public safety while making sure communities—especially marginalized ones—are treated fairly and with respect.

As an immigrant and small business owner, I’ve seen how much trust matters between police and the communities they serve, especially for workers and people without citizenship. Policing should focus on de-escalation, strong accountability for excessive force, and training that truly addresses racial and cultural bias, so people like me and my workers don’t feel targeted or afraid. At the same time, we need well-trained officers who know our neighborhoods, work with community leaders, and prioritize serious crimes so everyone can feel safe on the job and at home.

As a Brazilian-born, liberal Catholic and a special education teacher, I see every day how compassion, patience, and clear communication can transform conflict and misunderstanding—skills we should also demand from our police. Policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, accountability for misuse of force, and stronger partnerships with communities, especially with families and youth. We can’t talk about “public safety” if some communities—often people of color and immigrants—don’t feel safe around those sworn to protect them. True safety comes when officers are held to high standards, supported with proper training and oversight, and work collaboratively with schools, social services, and neighborhoods to prevent harm before it happens.

As a retired teacher and a Catholic with traditional, conservative values, I believe we should respect and support our police while also holding them to high standards of fairness and professionalism. We need strong, ongoing training on de-escalation and recognizing unconscious bias, along with clear body-camera policies and accountability when officers misuse force. At the same time, officers must not be so afraid of criticism that they hesitate to act when public safety is at risk. Good policing, like good teaching, requires both firm authority and genuine respect for every person’s dignity.

My mommy and daddy say police should be nice to everybody and not hurt people just because they look different, and I think that’s important because it makes me feel safe. I think police should talk and listen first and only use force if someone is really in danger, like if a bad person is trying to hurt people. If police learn in school how to be fair and kind and know our names in the neighborhood, then kids like me won’t be scared of them and they can still keep us safe.

As a Catholic, a nurse, and a mom, I believe we have a moral obligation to protect human dignity in every setting—including in how we police our communities. I support strong, consistent accountability for excessive force, mandatory de-escalation and bias training, and more mental-health and social-service partnerships so officers aren’t asked to handle every crisis with a gun and a badge. At the same time, I know from working in a hospital how crucial safety and order are, so reforms should be designed to help good officers do their jobs more safely and fairly, not to undermine them.

As someone who believes in both public safety and justice, I think policing needs stronger accountability measures, better training in de-escalation, and mandatory body cameras to reduce bias and excessive force. We should invest more in community-based programs, mental health services, and alternatives to armed responses so police are not the first or only resort for every problem. At the same time, officers who do their jobs responsibly deserve support and fair working conditions, because real safety depends on trust and respect between the community and the people sworn to protect it.

I think police should be kind and fair to everyone and only use force when they really have to, like if someone is in danger. They should get special training to help them stay calm, not judge people by what they look like, and listen carefully before acting. I feel safer knowing there are rules and cameras so if something bad happens, adults can find out what went wrong and fix it.

Police officers have a tough job, and we need to support them, but we also need clear standards and accountability to make sure everyone is treated fairly. I think better training on de-escalation, body cameras, and swift, transparent investigations when force is used can help reduce bias and rebuild trust without tying officers’ hands. At the same time, we should focus on strong community relationships and backing good cops so they can keep neighborhoods safe and respond decisively when real threats arise.

As a university professor and lifelong Democrat, I believe policing must be guided by evidence-based reforms that reduce bias and excessive force while still ensuring communities are genuinely safe. That means mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training grounded in social science, transparent data collection and public reporting on stops and use-of-force, and independent civilian oversight with real authority. We should also reinvest in mental health services, social work, and community-based violence prevention so that armed police are not the default response to every social problem. Public safety and civil rights are not competing goals; when policing is fair, accountable, and community-centered, both are strengthened.

As someone who believes in both public safety and equal opportunity, I think policing needs to be grounded in clear, transparent standards, strong accountability, and good data. We have the tech to track use-of-force, identify bias patterns, and support better training in de-escalation and communication, and we should be using it aggressively and publicly. Officers should be held to consistent, enforced rules, but also given the tools, staffing, and support they need to do their jobs safely and fairly. In the end, you don’t really have safety if whole communities don’t trust the people who are supposed to protect them.

As someone who spent a career working on power lines where one mistake can cost a life, I believe policing should be guided by strict, transparent standards, strong accountability, and constant training—especially on de-escalation and bias—so officers know exactly what’s expected of them. We need to protect both the public and the officers, which means body cameras, clear use-of-force rules, and swift, fair investigations when things go wrong, but also making sure departments have the resources and staffing to respond quickly and safely. I’d like to see more community-based policing where officers actually know the neighborhoods they serve, because trust and familiarity go a long way toward reducing unnecessary confrontations without sacrificing public safety.

As a conservative, law-abiding small business owner who’s spent a lifetime working with my hands, I have a lot of respect for the hard job police officers do and believe they need strong support, good training, and the tools to keep our communities safe. At the same time, every person deserves to be treated fairly, and departments should use better training, body cameras, and clear, consistent standards so that bias is minimized and excessive force is dealt with quickly and openly. We don’t need to “defund” the police; we need to hold them to high professional standards while giving them the resources and backing to do their job right.
